content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Resource Depot & Smelting Facility at base position (x=-4.5, y=18.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=-4.5, y=18.5) serving as central storage.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-3.0, y=19.0) for iron smelting – recent diagnostics confirm improved output (≈40 iron-plate) and a WORKING status.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-4.0, y=21.0) for copper plate production.
• Burner Inserter at (x=0.5, y=21.5) with drop position at (x=0.5, y=20.5).

### Automation Lab & Steam Power System (Integrated System)
Consists of:
• Lab at (x=-7.5, y=18.5) configured for automation research.
• Boiler at (x=-5.5, y=24.0) now operating with 10 coal and reporting WORKING status.
• Steam Engine (Generator) at (x=-0.5, y=24.5) reconnected with optimal power output.
• Offshore Pump at (x=-7.5, y=25.5) operating normally.
• Electricity Group comprising small electric poles at positions (x=-0.5, y=11.5), (x=-7.5, y=15.5), (x=-4.5, y=15.5), (x=3.5, y=19.5) and (x=1.5, y=22.5).
• Two PipeGroups forming the fluid network at (x=-10.5, y=16.5) & (x=-12.5, y=18.5) and at (x=-8.5, y=20.5) & (x=-2.5, y=21.5).

### Copper Cable Factory at position (x=1.5, y=19.5)
Consists of:
• Assembling Machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5) running the copper-cable recipe – recent reconnection routines have transitioned it to full WORKING status.
• Burner Inserter at (x=1.5, y=17.5).
• Input Chest at (x=2.5, y=17.5) for receiving copper plates.
• Output Chest at (x=1.5, y=21.5) for dispatching copper-cable.
• Dedicated Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-5.5, y=21.5).
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=0.5, y=17.5) connecting production outputs.
• Additional Burner Inserters at (x=2.5, y=16.5) and (x=3.5, y=17.5).

### Copper Extraction System (adjacent to the copper smelting furnace)
Consists of:
• Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=23.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=22.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=24.5).
• Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-3.5, y=26.5).
• Chest Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=27.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=26.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=28.5).
• Belt Source Inserter with extraction drop at (x=-3.5, y=25.5).

### Extraction Belt Depot at position (x=3.5, y=15.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5) serving as the belt depot.
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=4.5, y=15.5) for copper plate conveyance.
• Depot Burner Inserter at (x=3.5, y=14.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=3.5, y=13.5).

### Belt Connection Target Setup for Copper Extraction
Consists of:
• Extraction Source: Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5).
• Extraction Inserter at (x=4.5, y=15.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=5.5, y=15.5).
• Manual Transport Belt Chain connecting the extraction inserter drop to the target inserter pickup:
 – Horizontal segments: (x=7.5, y=15.5) and (x=8.5, y=15.5) placed; note that placement at (x=6.5, y=15.5) failed due to an existing entity.
 – Vertical segments: Positioned along x=8.5 with segments at (y=14.5), (y=13.5), (y=12.5), and (y=11.5) placed; placement at (x=8.5, y=10.5) encountered an occupancy error.
• New Target Inserter at (x=8.5, y=9.5) with pickup at (x=8.5, y=10.5) and drop at (x=8.5, y=8.5).
• Belt Chain Burner Inserter Refueling Subsystem:
 – Burner Inserters at (x=6.5, y=9.5), (x=7.5, y=9.5), (x=8.5, y=9.5), and (x=5.5, y=11.5) have been successfully refueled.
 – Burner Inserters at (x=3.5, y=14.5) and (x=5.5, y=14.5) still present fuel warnings.

(All previously defined structures persist. Recent steps have focused on system-wide integration testing, automated maintenance scheduling, network reconfiguration, and expansion protocol deployment to enhance module connectivity and operational stability.)

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Fuel Management Consistency
 – Ensure continuous fuel supply for burner-driven modules by scheduling timely auto‐refuel routines and verifying inventory levels before operation.

• Power Network Stability
 – Validate and secure power connections for critical entities (like assembling machines and steam engines) by confirming reconnection protocols and allowing adequate synchronization delays.

• Transport Belt Placement and Alignment
 – Pre-verify target tile occupancy to prevent placement failures (e.g. “entity already exists” errors) and maintain strict grid alignment for uninterrupted belt chain connections.

• Resource Input Verification
 – Confirm that required ingredients are available before initiating smelting; align input inventories with production demands to avoid “NO_INGREDIENTS” warnings.

• Automated Protocol Timing
 – Introduce sufficient wait intervals between auto-maintenance, blueprint updates, and reconfiguration routines to allow subsystems to stabilize before the next operation.
